conclusion: To find the difference in electric potential energy of the small ball when it reaches the highest point compared to its electric potential energy at point O.
The ball starts from point O with an initial velocity v0 at an angle θ to the opposite direction of the electric field.
The ball is subject to gravity (mg) and the electric force (qE).
Given the ball moves along the straight line at angle θ, we need to consider the components of these forces along this direction.
Since the ball moves along a straight line, the net force along this line must be zero.
The electric force component along the direction of motion is qE cos(θ).
The gravitational force component along this direction is mg cos(θ).
For motion along the line, qE cos(θ) = mg cos(θ).
The electric potential energy change is determined by the work done by the electric force.
The ball moves to a point directly opposite the electric field, which corresponds to a displacement in the x-direction.
When the ball reaches the highest point, its vertical velocity is zero.
Use the vertical component of motion to determine height: v0y = v0 sin(θ).
The work done by the electric force is W = qE ⋅ d, where d is the distance in the direction of the electric field.
The distance d can be related to the maximum height by d = v0^2 sin^2(θ)/(2g).
The change in electric potential energy is ΔU = qE ⋅ d = mg tan(θ) ⋅ v0^2 sin^2(θ)/(2g).
The difference in electric potential energy when the ball reaches the highest point compared to point O is ΔU = 1/2 m v0^2 sin(2θ).
This result comes from simplifying the expression using trigonometric identities.
